Leonardo da Vinci: I would bring back Leonardo da Vinci because he was a polymath who excelled in multiple fields such as art, science, and engineering. He is known for his iconic works such as the Mona Lisa and The Last Supper, as well as his scientific and engineering pursuits. I would be fascinated to see how he would approach the modern world and what new innovations he would come up with.

Cleopatra: I would bring back Cleopatra because she was a powerful and intelligent queen who ruled Egypt during a time of great political and cultural change. I would be interested in learning more about her leadership style, her relationships with other world leaders, and her strategies for maintaining power in a male-dominated world.

Mahatma Gandhi: I would bring back Mahatma Gandhi because he was a visionary leader who played a pivotal role in India's struggle for independence from British rule. I would be interested in learning more about his philosophy of nonviolent resistance, his approach to conflict resolution, and his strategies for inspiring and mobilizing people to work towards a common goal.

Marie Curie: I would bring back Marie Curie because she was a pioneering scientist who made groundbreaking discoveries in the field of radioactivity. She was the first woman to win a Nobel Prize and the first person to win two Nobel Prizes in different fields. I would be interested in learning more about her scientific discoveries, her struggles as a woman in a male-dominated field, and her impact on the world of science.

Martin Luther King Jr.: I would bring back Martin Luther King Jr. because he was a civil rights leader who played a crucial role in the American civil rights movement. He is known for his speeches, his leadership skills, and his advocacy for nonviolent resistance. I would be interested in learning more about his strategies for organizing protests and strikes, his approach to working with politicians and government officials, and his vision for a more just and equitable society.
